topic.title: FileServer Internet offline with Tor?
topic.body:
In the browser I have Port Closed, Tor Always, but when ZeroNet started, [05:11:55] FileServer Internet offline was the first error. I can browse sites, but all file transfers are dead (I constantly get Announce to 0 trackers in 0.xxxs, failed). How to debug?

```
 echo 'PROTOCOLINFO' | nc 127.0.0.1 9051
250-PROTOCOLINFO 1
250-AUTH METHODS=COOKIE,SAFECOOKIE,HASHEDPASSWORD COOKIEFILE="/tor/tor-cookie/file"
250-VERSION Tor="0.2.8.2-alpha"
250 OK
```

topic.title: Getting .bit to work
topic.body:
So I went to plugins directory and moved disabled-Dnschain to Dnschain
I also went to my site's content.json and added "domain": ".....bit",
Then I executed siteSign --publish and started using the defaults (I understand 1Name2NXVi1RDPDgf5617UoW7xA6YrhM9F is the default dot-bit resolver).

But:
1) When I click on my site, I get <domain>.bit, it's not found
2) When I go to http://127.0.0.1:43110/1Name2NXVi1RDPDgf5617UoW7xA6YrhM9F/, I don't see my .bit domain listed there. 

It's been 24 hours since I made the update so I thought if 1Name2NXVi1RDPDgf5617UoW7xA6YrhM9F fetches periodically it may take a while, but now I'm wondering if my procedure was correct. 

Q:
1) Do we still need to enable Dnschain or not (if we use the default resolver 1Name2NXVi1RDPDgf5617UoW7xA6YrhM9F)?
2) How frequently does 1Name2NXVi1RDPDgf5617UoW7xA6YrhM9F update the list?

I think my data on Namechain is correct - I have only one site. This is my Current ZeroNet related value from Namecha.in UI (sorry I prefer to keep the domain and site private):
```
    "<domain>": {
        "": "<site-address>"
    }
```

topic.title: What kinds of content & sites is ZeroNet suitable for? (AKA "Killer Apps")
topic.body:
While technically a lot can be done, some things are more suitable than others. 
For example, in terms of content type, movies don't work so well yet. 
In terms of applications (forums, downloads, blogs, etc.) it seems to me that blogs are not great and I'll explain why. 
Some time ago somebody said all ZN blogs are about ZN. Duh. Of course they are, because if you want more than 50 people to read your posts, you should post on clearnet. It is expected that ZN blogs would be about ZN (development, how-to posts, announcements and such).  While they're really helpful to those who create content and develop for ZN, they don't directly attract new users to ZN. 

Personally I think a forum software that's easy to manage in terms of adding and deleting members would be interesting. This ZeroTalk forum is quite good and can be cloned, but it'd have to have a little bit better member management (for example, make it possible to send out invites to a user's ZeroID, and delete misbehaving users).

Also a DropBox-like app would be interesting: if you want (reasonable) anonymity you can access it over Tor, if not, then just use plain ZeroNet.

ZeroMail: I'd like to be able to use it, but it creates a lot of activity on my HDD. Also I think if it becomes popular, users' accounts will be spammed. 

What do you guys think?

topic.title: DIY workaound for blocking the spammers and crap-creators
topic.body:
##Intro

While we wait for a native ZeroNet anti-spam system, here's what you can do to eliminate the spammers on community sites you visit the most.

##How?

On Tor Browser (and FireFox), do this if you haven't already:

1) Install AdBLock Plus and disable permitted ads
2) Install Element Hiding Helper for AdBlock Plus
3) Navigate to ZN site that you visit most often and press CTRL+SHIFT+F3 to activate Element Hiding Helper
4) Block the motherfucker! 

##Walkthrough: Blocking `1B5iUj9wVHFvsujUy7e9yt1Q6t2RTJ77yt` aka `besmart@zeroid.bit`

Let's say I mainly visit http://127.0.0.1:43110/Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/ and personal blogs. For the personal blogs it's easy - I don't visit (and seed) a blog if it's crap. 
The problem is blogs/forums/sites that serve the community because "everyone is welcome" (bad idea!). 

Why? As any other network, ZeroTalk has a number of known spammers such as besmart so for now we want to ignore them, rather than "fight them".

All right. Visit http://127.0.0.1:43110/Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/ and spot one of his posts you don't like (truth be told, it's not like he's capable of "discussion" on anything but one topic; it's safe to say we won't miss anything valuable - just find *any* of his posts in the feed). Do not click on the post title.

Now hit `CTRL+SHIFT+F3` and use your mouse to hover over his post in the ZeroTalk feed. This won't work from the main feed on ZN home page. You must be browsing ZeroTalk (see the URL above). 

Once you select the rectangle you will see the proposed custom filter that looks similar to this:
`127.0.0.1###topic_1_1B5iUj9wVHFvsujUy7e9yt1Q6t2RTJ77yt`

If you got this right his post in the feed will disappear. Press `OK` only if you got this right, otherwise cancel and use `CTRL+SHIFT+F3` again. 

I think it should be possible to generalize this filter to something with wildcards (`topic_*` instead of `topic_1`), like this: `127.0.0.1###topic_*_1B5iUj9wVHFvsujUy7e9yt1Q6t2RTJ77yt`, but I need to understand more about https://adblockplus.org/filters before I can confirm that.

##Issues

This is can get labor intensive, but at the moment it's very manageable. There's only about 20-30 spammers and I only care about ZeroTalk at the moment. 

Notice that blocking the idiot in the site feed still doesn't block his actual post (if you were to click on it before you hid it and navigate to it later you'll still see it), but that's not a problem - why would you visit that post anyway? You just don't want to see it in the feed you visit and you'll never hit the page itself unless you click on random links or search to find it.

Another issue is that you unwillingly seed his content. I've started experimenting with that (see Future Work before).

So what is that idiot (besmart@zeroid.bit) going to do? He will create new accounts. Let him.

I just need to run a scheduled search script and find couple of keywords that repeat across 2 or more posts and can automatically extract his ZeroID and filter the shit out of him. 

##Future Work

I am still experimenting with several other approaches:

* Create a list of block-activating keywords; create a shell script that searches for those terms, isolates the post owner's ZeroNet ID's, deletes his mirrored content, makes his directories read-only and chown's them by root:root. I got this working but ZeroNet doesn't tolerate that well. 
* Same workflow as above, but to create auto-generated AblockPlus filter with wildcards. 
* Create a ZeroNet or `.onion` site that shares Adblock filter so that the workload can be shared and users can simply set their AdBlock Plus to get updates from the network.
* Create a site that requires whitelisting (which can be automated). I already have a solution for this, but I don't have a reason to deploy it yet (because although it's automated it still requires some management and I don't have the time). 

All these approaches are inferior to a native or ZeroNet-integrated anti-spam and reputation system, but until we have one a mix of these will do for me. 

One important point I want to repeat is that there is **no issue with personal sites**. 

If we persist on further decentralization, each site will be a personal site (even if it's community-oriented) and as soon as a private site that you visit becomes neglected, you can fork it and keep going. Someone (or better, several people) could fork this site (ZeroTalk) and offload management tasks from @nofish. Of course this site is "personal" too, but @nofish runs it as showcase community site. The idea is that there be many clones with different angles and focuses, but many fail to understand that and expect somebody will do something for them. 

Related to this, notice how socialists/SJWs on this forum constantly bitch about the "need" for censorship, reputation, ratings, etc. but not a single one has done anything about it. For example, donate 0.05 BTC to develop this feature, or actually try to do something about it, such as fork this site, rename it and keep the spammers out on a daily basis.

4_1By85xCDz7VyZEq9WjmhtbNaPKimQwhPLp.body: Yeah, it's very easy: don't let others access the file with your identity info.

8_1J3rJ8ecnwH2EPYa6MrgZttBNc61ACFiCj.body: I read the FAQs. One thing I'm not sure is if one enables Tor and in addition has port 15441 open, it seems most connections go over clearnet. What is the purpose of having Tor in that case?

> [muja](#comment_82_17i7Y7r8nTaCfLbCAuaKyc4R5BbKZYU2Hr): From what I understand, the port is always closed when using --tor always. What operating system do you use?

That's exactly why I'm asking. https://zeronet.readthedocs.io/en/latest/faq/#how-to-use-zeronet-with-tor doesn't say what parameter to use. So `--tor always` is what we should use?

> [grez](#comment_3_19arYgVKguUamTqtYGu6T9FSUsr19CyEcG): Is it possible to publish some file to ZeroNet that is not signed by anyone? Actually, I want to create a chat that is not require ZeroID and I don't see any other ways how to bring it to life.

http://127.0.0.1:43110/Board.ZeroNetwork.bit/ doesn't require ZeroID

> [cyanlink](#comment_4_1HyGdgAam1jDwQzrMmAJavFGMZoCpsVZJA): need to know:which "privatekey" should i input when i visit a non localhost portal?the first line of users.json?

Well it says `auth_privatekey` so that's most likely your private key. But I don't know what is the situation in which one may need to enter this anywhere. I use to to sign my site content and nothing else.

* Will ZeroBlog support tags (so that posts can be organized)
* How to add multiple links to left-hand side of ZeroBlog? It seems only one link is displayed even if there are multiple rows.

> [grez](#comment_20_19arYgVKguUamTqtYGu6T9FSUsr19CyEcG): When I see "Content published to 5 peers" message, does this indicate, that 5 peers already downloaded my content, or only that the content was announced to them? How can I find out when they downloaded it, especially on sites with optional content, such as 0chan?

> [ancap](#comment_20_1FYXQGLBeNabf5jZHgP4CwzbmJSKaK4oMz): Will ZeroBlog support tags (so that posts can be organized)
> How to add multiple links to left-hand side of ZeroBlog? It seems only one link is displayed even if there are multiple rows.

Replying to my own question (#1): there's an enhanced ZeroBlog already (http://127.0.0.1:43110/19k2nhubaYsDJNPHL6iNs3D2K9Mgj66P4R) so it seems tags aren't far away.
Does `zeronet.py sitePublish` de-anonymize Tor users? It seems it talk directly to trackers.

> [grez](#comment_21_19arYgVKguUamTqtYGu6T9FSUsr19CyEcG): No, if you use python zeronet.py --tor always siteSign <site_address> --publish command (I think it is a good idea to add this in FAQ).

Thanks, that's exactly what I noticed and I also think that's important enough for FAQs because it can ruin effects of `./zeronet.py --tor always` for network participants.
(I didn't know that `--tor always` can be issued before sitePublish, online help doesn't give that impression and I think I tried to use it after sitePublish. Maybe that would have worked if I used your order. I'll have to try that).

> [grez](#comment_20_19arYgVKguUamTqtYGu6T9FSUsr19CyEcG): When I see "Content published to 5 peers" message, does this indicate, that 5 peers already downloaded my content, or only that the content was announced to them? How can I find out when they downloaded it, especially on sites with optional content, such as 0chan?

Did you find the exact answer to this?

Here's what I see:

`[15:32:32] Site:1XXX..vuLu Publishing content.json to 4/13 peers (connected: 2) diffs: [u'data/data.json'] (8.03k)...`

I would say that:

* 13 visited the site
* Some suspended updates (Pause), some disappeared from the network
* 4 are mirroring the site
* 2 are online and will receive latest updates

You could see (from the logs) which content was downloaded (should be all unless the files are larger than the "manual download limit").

> [daozen](#comment_1_1Pm6qTHfW1vkbNodfwZ1Ku2nHJaKZzy15i): I agree with freedom of speech, but can we downvote posts like this? No downvote option makes it easy for trolls to spam and discredit Zeronet. 

What good would that do? 
To a troll a vote down _or_ up is an up-vote. 
They get pissed off when they're ignored.  (Even banning an account doesn't work because it costs 0 to create a new one).

IMO the next step would be that users set up interest/topic sites where they can control access and also censor, if they want.  Currently one problem is there's only 1-2 busy ZN sites (that I know of) because people mostly look to comment rather than create content (which makes sense since the audience is so small). 
Then all the trolls also gather here which makes it hard to manage since the admin is just one. 

Ideally there would be a network-wide ratings system for sites to tap in to, but it doesn't exist. So for time being, more smaller sites with more admins, and invite-only access is what is available now.  

Maybe we should also experiment with real-world identity systems. That destroys the anonymity but maybe some ZN sites would benefit from that approach.

> [nofish](#comment_640_1J3rJ8ecnwH2EPYa6MrgZttBNc61ACFiCj): looks like something wrong with your tor connection, easiest way to test zeronet.py --debug peerPing boot3rdez4rzn36x.onion 15441

It was this bug: https://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=816559

Finally fixed the damn thing...  The SOCKS port # wasn't not consistent (between what ZeroNet wanted to use and what Tor had)

> [circle](#comment_6_1XGf6G78ZwZwz4FeZBtmzxtKAsTicgaBN): I think it would be better to find another way around, for example, keeping the size of the inbox below 10MB can be achieved by archiving old mails, or using ipfs or something like that, I'm sure there will be a perfect solution for this, but for now, IMHO, the architecture is not capable doing that (forcing people to host big things, just because they have spare disk space, or not use the service)

Those ideas (archiving or IPFS) don't make any sense.  Delete your old messages or archive them yourself. 

The inability to save too many messages is a good security feature.

1_12zyC2je1V8Sfq6C5d6CSzUkjYf4bEdva4.body:
> [david](#comment_2_15WPKoXwHMPcPvciHw3N12MxrYWsWD7WVp): I think he wants to know what the difference is between the tor modes "enable" (default) and "always"."Enable" does not always use the tor network?

`always` is always and only, `enable` is "also".

> [vahcam](#comment_1_12zyC2je1V8Sfq6C5d6CSzUkjYf4bEdva4): No that is not the question, if I don't use Tor, would surfing here in ZeroNet respects my anonymity ?

Define anonymity. 
Nobody knows who you are, so you are anonymous. 
Can people learn your IP address if you're not using Tor? Yes. 
If you care, use Tor and take other measures. ZeroNet is not a privacy tool and as @klauszimmermann already pointed out, privacy and anonymity weren't the primary design goals. There are privacy tools such as Tor Browser that you have at your disposal. You're responsible for your own privacy, not ZeroNet.

> [david](#comment_3_15WPKoXwHMPcPvciHw3N12MxrYWsWD7WVp): So when does it use tor, and when does it not?

It uses tor in the both cases (enable & always), but it uses only Tor in the latter (always).  
http://127.0.0.1:43110/12Q63F1Nh2hVoYkBEfvKcoTWihsrUvvuLu/ has some possibly useful info on this topic.

> [dankestdungeon](#comment_5_1NkUo6SseJPa4FP4CFNzNWfqTzGYoQK6VQ): Yeah, but then, with the default configuration, it shouldn't say "TOR: OK" on the top of the start page. That's misleading. Most people associate tor with internet anonymity.

* Everyone is welcome to submit enhancement request at https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/issues.
* You can submit documentation enhancements at https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/Documentation/blob/master/docs/faq.md or elsewhere in this repo
* `TOR: OK` means 'Tor is being used'. It is meant for users who otherwise may not be able to download or publish information that is blocked. Certainly a settings page with detailed privacy oriented settings would be welcome, but it's a free project and without donations in labor or money, it's going to take longer than it otherwise would.

23_1CMYxdit4qq9QGk9DYRu2ruRPd2YDGckH8.body:
> [lukipuki](#comment_64_1CMYxdit4qq9QGk9DYRu2ruRPd2YDGckH8): I found something here: https://codepen.io/gil--/pen/bNxZWg
> But I am not sure how should I put this into the existing .html .css and .js of the my zeronet blog. Do I just add this, or would this interfere somehow with existing things ?

Why don't you try and let us know if it works. I'm also curious.

"Watch later" would be nice (not instead, but in addition to what you want) because many access the network via Tor which is slow and vids can't be played unless they're downloaded first. And if I'm not mistaken, files larger than 1MB have to be manually downloaded, but then you have to wait, which is where "Watch later" would make more convenient.

> [lukipuki](#comment_67_1CMYxdit4qq9QGk9DYRu2ruRPd2YDGckH8): .On the other hand it reduces the amount of shared content from your (or my) site, resulting in low functionality for most people.

Maybe it would reduce it less than otherwise - it's hard to tell in advance.
From my own experience, some Zeronet sites I simply have to Pause after I visit them because my Tor connection isn't that good, so I postpone re-sync until next time I visit (and if I don't, I don't burden my Tor connection).
I do this only with busy/large sites and I assume many would do the same with video content...

Also, your comment reminded me of this: say I have a copy of your HTML/JS files and 5 of 30 files (3 I set to Watch Later, 2 I watched while online). Now a guy downloads this site from me. What happens if they click on video #6 which I don't have a copy of? I don't know exactly, but as I said in the previous paragraph, I doubt I could have all or even most of your video files that are > 1 MB in size - it's simply impossible. 

 (I think the project leader said (ZN on Github) he'll change the way downloads work so that each file that belongs to a site is downloaded from a different source)

1_1BLPKyrF2D4ertte6JnAa6oWAMYzZGwKQz.body:
> [up4](#comment_13_1BLPKyrF2D4ertte6JnAa6oWAMYzZGwKQz): my bad: I confirm that the json syntax errors were the cause of the non-updates.

I'm still curious about your theory about the connection between ZeroName and Namecoin blockchain updates!

> [up4](#comment_14_1BLPKyrF2D4ertte6JnAa6oWAMYzZGwKQz): if the domain's JSON value is malformed syntactically, it won't be added or updated to ZeroName
> the JSON value can only be set by the domain's owner

Yeah but that's just for your own `d/domain`. If you mess it up, ZeroName will simply not find a valid entry. 
Wouldn't it be ridiculous if it were possible that I make a malformed update to my Namecon domain and take ZeroName (and maybe a bunch of other `.bit` resolvers) down?

> [up4](#comment_15_1BLPKyrF2D4ertte6JnAa6oWAMYzZGwKQz): 
> I was worried for a bit that there was a problem with the trusted zerosite that is used system-wide for Namecoin resolution and it happened not to be the case.

I understand your point.

If I'm not mistaken (I'm too busy to check now) there's a place where you can decide your own ZeroName resolver, so if ZeroName were to be taken over, one could redirect ZeroNet to use another site. But until a good replacement is setup, .bit resolution wouldn't work (or would work incorrectly to cause more damage).

Sadly there's no SPV client yet, so it is what it is at the moment.

3_16JexJdvqRHRobrHnkbSWmdC8pfkkQzmiU.body:
> If the site is illegal and any files of the site are on your computer, the feds can charge you with hosting an illegal site.

Everything is illegal these days so we may as well ignore the law (as long as we know we're unlikely to get caught). 

People could probably claim ignorance, although in places where the legal system is crap that won't get one very far.

It would be nice if Tor browser be made mandatory to provide a better protection to ZN users, but there's a whole bunch of crybabies who want ZN to accommodate clearnet and so on. Depending on what direction the devs head in, we could get a better (security and privacy first) or worse (convenience first) ZN.

@testingzeronet12, this isn't news to experienced Tor users and ZN doesn't make any claims about anonymity that this post negates. If people don't make unwarranted assumptions, they'll be okay. If they don't read anything, these warnings won't help them either.

> [testingzeronet12](#comment_17_1CMjV2r4EBpFt8VCcWWZKDysZXPcPExRNN): And the usage of Tor could be made idiot-proof so that anyone knows how to use it. I think the developers already did a good job already though. 

It's very hard to make things secure, even with Tor. Anyone who wants very good security should not run ZeroNet on a non-secure device such as your regular computer. ZN+Tor is the 2nd best choice and I think the Windows bundle does that. 
 
Secure deletion: I am not entirely convinced. If you simply don't click on random crap, you won't end up with unwanted content on your computer. If you think what is preferable - not download unwanted content, or being able to wipe unwanted content. I'd say the former is more important and it'd be better if we worked towards some sort of reputation system that can be used to lower the likelihood of unwanted downloads as well as to prevent spam and many other things. Even if you delete some unwanted content, if you left traces (IP address at the telco, ZeroNet log on your PC, etc.), securely deleting the content won't help you in most jurisdictions. 
Like with Tor, the only reasonable way is to use a secure OS (e.g. Tails) and not persist anything at all. And most users can't be bothered to do that.

`user.deleteSiteData` (or whatever is used to delete a site) could contain a call to the shred command, but on Windows it seems there's no equivalent (maybe a CoreUtils binary could be added to ZN bundle?).

8_1QBLGLcgKfcpfLmiDYuDzUKVXFfmTAew55.body:
No, it's the way things work right now. You download contents of sites you visit. ZeroMail the site contains all the messages so that's what it is.

There are better ways and as this situation becomes less and less bearable I'm sure we'll see innovation in this space. 
There's no reason sites couldn't collect money from users, for example, so that messages are fewer as people delete them (or pay more). And maybe they could be set to auto-expire, and those who want to keep them could clone individual messages to their own archive.

4_1CMjV2r4EBpFt8VCcWWZKDysZXPcPExRNN.body:
Personally I'd like to see a method for this which can use (bitcoin) micropayments (look at 21.co's developer examples - you can charge micro amounts, e.g. 20 satoshi per second, although in our case we'd need something like 20 satoshi per MB served) so that there's a choice between paid and free. 
I copy/seed some ZN sites that I think are beneficial, but I'd do 100x more (seed anything, basically, except content objectionable to me) if I could cover my costs.
While free is great, I do that now, I am not interested in doing much more without being compensated. And to be honest there are projects out there (Storj, for example) that will make it convenient to resell one's disk space, so if one can make some pocket change that way he won't donate 100 GB to just because it's cool.

> [testingzeronet12](#comment_15_1CMjV2r4EBpFt8VCcWWZKDysZXPcPExRNN): This could hypothetically turn the ZeroNet network into a defacto paid-for service due to the price structure. I'm not saying I disagree with you, but what solutions would there be to stop ZeroNet turning into this?

Notice that I am not arguing against free peer-assisted hosting on ZN - as I said I do it now. 
The difference is that for some content there won't be enough (or any) free seeders. 

@nofish says if one has valuable content, he won't have problems. Yes, so free may work for those. But there are always others who would like to pay. It's a choice thing. If someone wants to pay (or wants to seed for money), why not let them? 
It's not like noone would seed a site for free because some other guy is already seeding it for 5000 satoshi/day. You said it yourself (if the content is good, it will be seeded for free).

There are several important cases where only paid seeding can work:
a) When the poster can't be online all the time. Say the publisher doesn't own a computer or can't afford to pay for this cloud service, but can pay 0.001 BTC to service that strives to be online 24x7
b) When the poster has content that requires a lot of resources (capacity, bandwidth, etc.)
c) When any sort of "customization" is important. Say I am from Burundi, I publish only in local language, so I want to ensure at least one seeder outside of Burundi always has a copy of my latest content

I could probably come up with more use cases, but the main point is that it's not really important what would people do. As long as there's a convenient way to do it (pay the seeders), good paid services *that ZeroNet users want* would thrive. 

We shouldn't be worried about people monetizing ZN (at least I wouldn't, since I only gain to stand if *in addition* to existing free services I could also pay a bit to get even more amazing paid services).

@nofish:

> This service provider gives you a full machine access and you can run any kind of applications on it.

In case of any "illegal" content, the provider is screwed, and the customer (ZN user) is screwed too unless he uses some very anonymous way to pay for this service and connect to it. So this is a good choice for some, but it has its risks for many others.
From a decentralization perspective, if something can be done efficiently in a decentralized way, why not provide a way to do it? (For example at the moment I can seed any ZN site and do it in a more private and cheaper way than any hosting company, but I don't know how the publisher can know that I am delivering on my promise to seed his site. In other words, how can some 1abcd...4565 site know that "testingzeronet12" is one of this mirrors and perhaps check his uptime.)

> [kingbudgie](#comment_4_17nphNHoGtz9EzvvTSSbZn7WHfM1ynpdsL): Well you can have seed boxes if you just leave zeronet running 24/7. So if you want seed boxes, just leave your running. Its what I do.

Haha, that's right! 
But he'd like you to use your resources to help him host massive ZN sites ;-)

> [testingzeronet12](#comment_19_1CMjV2r4EBpFt8VCcWWZKDysZXPcPExRNN): I was thinking of doing this in a less power-intensive way by setting up a RaspBerry Pi as a seedbox. Does ZeroNet work on Raspberry Pi?
> In addition to being power-saving, installing ZeroNet on a Raspberry Pi and using it as a seedbox means it can also be portable, ie, you can just seed from a free Wifi hotspot, as long as there is a power-bank attached to it and you SSH'ed into the Raspberry Pi earlier. This would provide a cheap, anonymous and cost-effective way to seed websites and videos.

You're not solving his problem. He wants people to seed tons of content for free. 

Running on Pi or any small device isn't a solution (how many GB can you seed and how well from an overloaded (free) WiFi hotspot). In fact it's less efficient (effort and cost vs. outcome) than seeding from a proper x86 server (see the comment at the very bottom of this page) for 1 euro per month.

@kingbudgie thanks, but I've been seeing for others for months now. I can seed 10's of TB's but I won't do it for free. 
@testingzeronet12 wants you to mirror and seed archive.org for free.

4_1BFTNXtYQDMCurqyg45KLmsV6oJD7bQSsH.body:
> what I'm saying is giving an option to the community to democratically classify them that is a totally different thing

Why "democratically"? I don't give a rat's ass what the majority thinks, so if that's what you want - to censor or hide content from users simply because the network is swamped with SJW's - NO. 

People should be able to read what they want. Perhaps that means the ability to block certain users' (all all *but* certain users' as in "whitelisting") content. 

@planespherev2, in ZeroNet the site owner can ban users (regardless of their rating, but ratings and reputations can be considered by site owners who want to leverage them, and such ratings should come from not just one source of truth). Or they can whitelist known good users and prune bad ones. 

Multiple reputation and trust systems can be created and used on ZeroNet. Maybe an API could be added that would  allow sites/developers to pull reputation data from different sources. I don't have anything against a reference implementation, but each site should be able to use their own.

> [planespherev2](#comment_51_1C9BTLZFTprZPJXkg9vPuZLBr3LeaxB7nj): Hi Ancap ;-)
> What ZeroNet needs more than a reputation system is a good captcha anouncing system. Less troublesome than in freenet with the super hard letter but something with multiple picture scheme to solve.This alone put most of trolls and spammers at distance.

Hi planespherev2, that too. Few months back I blogged (here on ZeroNet) how spammers begun to infest the network probably due to its increasing popularity (but I still don't get it - the ROI must be terrible compared to clearnet). 
It's a good problem to have but it doesn't seem so critical yet (except on 2-3 more popular ZN sites such as this one, but even here it can be handled manually). I need to think about it in coming days and weeks. 
I like whitelists, but they don't scale and people "turn" so some other mechanisms will be necessary to contain the zombies once ZN becomes more popular.

2_1AWKKjCvCFvUbmrbBtqrMSfAGZ8D6tAVHt.body:
You'd have to have a local or external resolver for .bit domains.
The Namecoin Project hasn't yet created software to run as trustless external resolver, so now it's only possible to install & run Namecoin locally and add a small program by Namecoin that provides DNS service to local host.
Then site.bit would resolve to it's IP address (not to 127.0.0.1:43110/site.bit) but you would lose the anonymity. 

It's too much hassle (for most people) and you can't expect regular users to bother with that.

The way ZeroNet provides this mapping is not trustless, but you don't have to trust the author more than you already do. Also you can verify that the sites are correctly mapped by checking in Namecoin explorers on the Web.

See the Namecoin site and forums for more info.

6_16w7UuJAHbt8YBa8zxHS7UFk9mq8Q5DpE4.body:
> IMPORTANT: Never change the Zeroid.bit input in User_contents. It'll just cause all of your future content to fail publishing, for some reason.

Your private key signs content published by the address so obviously the address must be what identifies the site owner, not a domain name that anyone could set to the same value.

This is documented in ZeroNet documentation. For example https://zeronet.readthedocs.io/en/latest/using_zeronet/create_new_site/ (clearnet!) explains the signing concept.

> [primo](#comment_1_1MbR4tiqHn8X3b7mEXXi1jaDdbJjbfCZSV): Yes, as long as there are people willing to seed the site, it's possible to create such a site on zeronet. 

It's a silly idea to begin with. What you are saying is it's possible to make a censorship resistant page as long as you can get people to work for free, forever. In other words, it's impossible. 
Why would anyone even bother volunteering to indiscriminately protect someone's garbage for free? 

> So, if you completely uninstall zeronet from your system after cloning zerotalk, there's no way to make changes to the cloned site afterwards, since the needed key is lost.

> [thisweb11](#comment_16_1D9w8AJTfqmn26iT2kF81B8HxXFfycXuXM): Thanks.   I understand that.  There is nothing anyone can do to stop a file being seeded , copied, changed and readdressed once its out there.   But what Im wondering if there is any way to set up a page/forum (like this one) and be able to prove (cryptographically) to anyone who uses that specific page that it can no longer be moderated or censored for all eternity because the key has been destroyed.  Something like a bitcoin burn address.   ?   I think it would be useful and possible to have such a feature.

Of course it's possible, but as always it's a matter of cost. It would be expensive. 
One could have an add on that checksums each user's post and store the checksum in an off- or on-blockchain database that is read-only.
And both ZeroNet and this other DB would have to remain available.

Another thing is ZN is not targeting that kind of use case.  Yours.network is (to some extent; now they still host stuff on their own servers) targeting curation. 

Right now storage here is "free", which isn't sustainable except for use cases where people voluntarily curate a site by "mirroring" it. It works for small sites because the incremental cost is low, but it can't work to store everything forever (even when the content is interesting just to 1 person). The checksum-to-outside-world feature could be added, but why would anyone spend their time to checksum the entire ZeroNet? I think the current approach is fine and people who want to curate could develop integration with external blockchains for such use cases.

There is no one in the government who will work for me as honestly and efficiently as I could get served in the private market, so I don't care who is or isn't something. I don't want any one of them and I don't want an "honest" person in their place either. 
On surface I am rooting for Trump because I can't stand the Clintons, but should Trump be elected that wouldn't many any difference to me. I wish I was more pragmatic and had the ability to shill for Clinton on social media because if elected she would bring the system down faster, but I simply can't bring myself to it.
 
Your approach to stealth income is nice: you are doing something for yourself *and others* right now (whereas other commenters want the government to do something for them, as usual by coercing their fellow men) and you are also working against the current system far more effectively than you could do by casting a vote in the next election.

2_1Buu3gEo6EcUijPE6dkSToaYzXKGnAgXFy.body: paste your Nginx configuration and logs and then someone may want to bother.

> [dock9](#comment_2_1Buu3gEo6EcUijPE6dkSToaYzXKGnAgXFy): Nice welcoming attitude towards a new user of a small community trying to contribute.

That's my point - you're not trying to contribute. You're just offloading the question to others. 
As you can see you've got no responses, perhaps because this is a small community that at this stage has more questions than answers.
Paste your config and logs and contribute your partial how-to recipe. 
You can create your own blog by cloning any other, explain what you did, paste the config and log and turn it into a how-to once you find a solution. Or is that too much to ask for?

> [dock9](#comment_3_1Buu3gEo6EcUijPE6dkSToaYzXKGnAgXFy):  A more welcoming tone would help grow the community faster, I might have written it off if not for devtest's response.

If you posted your config and logs the first time you would have had an answer earlier and provided others with an opportunity to actually learn something. It's that simple. 

>  how do you know I'm not trying to contribute?

You posted 2 (open ended) questions without sharing any information in those topics that would help the next person accomplish something. 
I see you also didn't help document what you learned in the documentation repo (https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/Documentation/commits/master) and it doesn't look like you blog about it here, so in all likelihood your "efforts" to fix your own problems aren't that helpful to anyone except yourself.

This reminds me of those community members who conclude their forum topics with "Solved", leaving everyone to wonder how they got so unlucky to come across that thread.
